com.robix.nexway
Class CognitionParams

java.lang.Object
  com.robix.nexway.CognitionParams
public class CognitionParams
extends java.lang.Object

These parameters control the behavior of the recognition algorithms in the Robix Shape-Vision software.

To better convey the meanings of the various parameters we will first outline how the original image is reduced to a group of non-overlapping "blobs" which are then compared to known object shapes. Some details of this process are omitted for simplicity: the specifics of the rounding procedure; exactly how the algorithms treat image edges; how dark images on a lighter background are processed (we assume bright objects below); etc.

  • Start with original rectangular RGB Image.
  • Apply redGain, greenGain and blueGain to each pixel.
  • Change to gray scale by adding the red, green and blue values for each pixel.
  • Reduce to 8 bits by scaling so that lightest pixel is 255.
  • Apply "median filter": Set pixel to average of itself and 8 the surrounding pixels. This simple filter smooths out high-frequency noise with a slight sacrifice of image detail.
  • Renormalize: scale so brightest = 255.
  • Compute background polynomial fit: Higher values can improve estimation of what is and is not background, but they also slow processing. Values are 0 (fastest: assumes constant, even background) to 5 (slowest: assumes highly variable background).
  • Subtract background from all pixels, flooring at 0.
  • Renormalize.
  • Compute average pixel value and the standard deviation.
  • Change 8-bit grayscale image to 1-bit (binary) image using avg, std dev, and thresholdGain.
  • Blobs, in this case distinct bright areas, are created.
  • Blobs that are too small, as determined by minBlobPixels and/or minBlobRatio, are discarded.
  • Blobs that are too large, as determined by maxBlobPixels, are discarded.
  • Proprietary recognition algorithms are then applied to the blobs and the resulting characteristics are compared to the characteristics of known objects. The output is a "Cognit" for each blob. (See maxFits, below).

brightObjects (boolean)
If true, recognition looks for brighter objects on a darker background. If false, darker objects on a brighter background are sought.

redGain, greenGain, blueGain (float)
Attenuation factors for red, green and blue, range is 0-1. These factors are applied before the image is converted to gray scale. For example, If the application was seeking only green on a dark background then setting greenGain to 1 (the default) and setting both redGain and blueGain to 0 would effectively brighten all green or partially green pixels and fade non-green objects into the background. This can help in the case where a green object overlaps (is partially in front of) a red object, but if the red object overlaps the green one then, even if red is attenuated there will still be a piece of the green object "missing" and recognition will be impaired.

bgPolyOrder (int)
As mentioned, at one point the estimated background is subtracted from the image. A zero-degree polynomial subtracts a constant amount from the image. Higher-order polynomials will do a more sophisticated estimate of the background but this can take significantly more processing time for each image.

thresholdGain (float)
Used when converting the 8-bit grayscale image to 1-bit image. Pixel values greater than the average value + the standard deviation of the values * thresholdGain get value 1. Other pixels get value 0. Value can be negative.

minBlobPixels, maxBlobPixels (int)
After the image has been separated into 1-bit pixels blobs, blobs are discarded if their area (in pixels) is less than minBlobPixels or greater than maxBlobPixels. These parameters are useful when the size (in pixels) of the image is known. If the size of the image is not known ahead of time, then minBlobPixels should be set to 0 and maxBlobPixels should be set to a high number (2,000,000,000 is about right). Doing this effectively removes these values from consideration and the minBlobRatio (below) then becomes the determining factor for minimum blob size that will be analyzed.

minBlobRatio (float)
After minBlobPixels and maxBlobPixels have been applied, blobs are discarded if their area (in pixels) is less than the total image area (in pixels) * minBlobRatio. minBlobRatio is generally used when you don't know ahead of time how large the image you will receive is. If you would rather use minBlobSize to determine minimum usable blob size, set minBlobRatio to 0.

maxFits (int)
Max number of Fits within a Cognit returned for a blob. "Cognit" is made-up word we use to describe what the program "thinks it sees". A cognit has, among other elements, a sorted list (usually short) of the program's best estimates of the identity of the blob. The elements of this list are known as the cognit's "Fits".

fitDisplayGain (int)
Affects fading (desaturation) of the green blob color in the Cognit Viewer. Lower green saturation indicates lower confidence in object identity. This value does not affect recognition itself, only the "cosmetics" of the cognit display.

Since:
1.1.0
See Also:
Cognit, Cam.getCognitionParams()

equals

public boolean equals(java.lang.Object obj)
